history.content:
If you didn't do super well in CS 70 probability, I feel like 140 has more to offer you than you're giving it credit for. Also if you're interested in probability for machine learning applications and CS 189, I don't think 126 prepares you any better than 140 does in that specific regard since 126 spends a lot more time focusing on stochastic processes ie. you'll have more knowledge of Markov chains through 126 than any of the other probability classes, but that's not going to help much/at all in 189. Also, you'd probably have a harder time in 126 than you would in 140 because 126 has 70 as a prerequisite and 140 teaches from the ground up, and while grades aren't the defining characteristic of learning, if you didn't do that well in CS 70 probability I'd caution you against 126.

--

Eh I did decently well in 126 and did horribly in CS 70. I think you can improve and the past doesn't completely define you. Ramchandran is also a super great prof and 126 staff is pretty poggers, I wouldn't be discouraged until you try it yourself. Don't live life with regrets and miss up this chance

If you didn't do super well in CS 70 probability, I feel like 140 has more to offer you than you're giving it credit for. Also if you're interested in probability for machine learning applications and CS 189, I don't think 126 prepares you any better than 140 does in that specific regard since 126 spends a lot more time focusing on stochastic processes ie. you'll have more knowledge of Markov chains through 126 than any of the other probability classes, but that's not going to help much/at all in 189. Also you'd probably have a harder time in 126 than you would in 140 because 126 has 70 as a prerequisite and 140 teaches from the ground up, and while grades aren't the defining characteristic of learning, if you didn't do that well in CS 70 probability I'd caution you against 126.

children.subject: What do you mean by "126 staff is pretty poggers"?

history.content:
Hello everyone, 

I am looking for brutally honest advice on whether or not I should take EECS 126. I am a data science major and would like to take the course in order to fulfill my probability requirement. I am interested in EECS 126 because of its applications to machine learning and to help prepare me to take CS 189 Fall 2022.

The reason I am worried about taking this class is because I took CS 70 this past summer (Summer 2021) and got absolutely thrashed. Despite spending a TON of time and effort on the class, I ended up with a B-.

I am not sure if I would get a lot out of taking a class like Data C140 after having taken CS 70, but I am honestly not sure if I could handle EECS 126, given how much I struggled in CS 70.  Furthermore, I have heard that EECS 126 is basically the most challenging EECS course that is offered. However, it is true that the classes I am planning on taking alongside EECS 126 next semester are not necessarily super challenging (Data 100, UGBA 147, and UGBA 106). 

Would love honest and direct feedback! :)
history.subject: Advice on whether or not I should take EECS 126
